results.title: Dr. No (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Ken Adam, Terence Young, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Dr.No was the first extraordinary adventure of the world’s most famous spy: James Bond. Sean Connery is 007: suave, charming and fearless; an expert on weapons, women, martinis and just about everything. Dr. No, a fanatical scientist plots to overtake the world but is ultimately defeated. Ursula Andress made her first screen appearance in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme and elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder have become part of the James Bond legend.

results.title: Janus. Eps 13 and 14: Burden of proof. A Lawful apprehension
results.creator_credit: Bill Hughes, Mandy Smith and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 13 and 14 of the television series Janus. “Burden of proof” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) finds the jury in a quandry - who do they believe, Dale Cassidy’s girlfriend Simone, or Steve Hennessey’s defacto wife Kirsty. Peter Faithful is put under fire on the witness stand by Michael Kidd with the suggestion that “revenge” on the Hennessey family for the murder of the two police officers at the Vic Bank armed robbery had become an obsession and that Faithful would go to any lengths to get a conviction. Pressure is also being put on Mal’s ex-girlfriend Sandy to tell the truth about the night of the murder of Patrick Clancy or face perjury. “A Lawful apprehension” (51 mins) (directed by Bill Hughes and Mandy Smith). On the strength of Sandy’s signed statement, Mal is arrested and bail application refused. The Hennessey family, Shirl, Steve and Kirsty, remain under surveillance. Peter Faithful still trying to do a deal with Steve Hennessey to dob his brother Mal in, in exchange for a new start for him and Kirsty under police protection. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Brett Swain, Leon Teague, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Pepe Trevor, Louise Siversen and Jane Menelaus.

results.title: Jazz
results.creator_credit: Ken Burns, BBC, WETA-TV and Florentine Films
results.brief_description: JAZZ is a comprehensive 4 volume series directed by Ken Burns that presents a detailed history of the musical form from its beginnings in the early 19th Century to its development up to the present day. Researched and produced over a six year period it is a thorough and broad study of the history of Jazz and its musicians and includes musicians’ biographies, renowned and rare recordings, footage of live performances, interviews with artists, historians, writers and critics and rare film clips and still photographs that form an extraordinary mix of interpretations of and insight into the characters, origins, development, techniques and reshaping of the diverse musical form that is Jazz.

results.title: Children and sports
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Michener’s World”.
Narrator, James Michener takes a close look at individual and team sports in the context of children’s involvement. He shows how children’s sport reflects society’s emphasis on achievement. Speaking with parents, coaches, physicians and athletes, Michener weighs the pros and cons of winning vs learning to meet challenges; healthy exercise vs exposure to injury.

results.title: Poland: the will to be
results.creator_credit: Albert Waller and Emlen House Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Michener’s World”.
Documentary film, narrated by James Michener, which looks at the history of Poland since its “first birth”. Shows the gaining of independence after Versailles, the invasion by Germany in 1939 and the Russian intervention during the war. Finally concentrates on the social-political structure of modern Poland. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: On the Birdsville Track
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
The most infamous bush track runs for 540 kilometres through Australia’s centre. Its history is one of personal hardships and tough pioneering people. Once goods were carried to remote cattle properties by camel and only in recent times was a road made across the sand dunes. Jack Absalom recalls the old times, meets newcomers to “The Birdsville Track” and has some sound travel advice. Rated: G

results.title: Rainbow's End
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
Every goldrush seems to begin with stories of people, picking up nuggets by the handful. This is a nostalgic journey to the richest square mile of real estate in the world. Jack Absalom traces the “Golden Rainbow” that the early diggers followed on their quest that would set them up for life. Rated: G

results.title: On the Road to Survival
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
Survival, says Jack Absalom, is a matter of commonsense and preparedness. In this film he demonstrates the techniques for safe travel that he has developed in his many years in the Outback. The program recreates a simple vehicle breakdown and highlights the potential for a tragedy. Rated: PG
